name: Freiburg
fun_fact: Fun fact: Freiburg is Germany's sunniest city and gateway to the Black Forest! The medieval B√§chle (little streams) running through the streets were built in 1120 for firefighting, and according to legend, if you accidentally step in one, you'll marry a Freiburg native. The city's stunning M√ºnster cathedral has a tower described in 1869 as 'the most beautiful tower on earth'!

hero_dishes.name: Lange Rote (Long Red Sausage)
hero_dishes.description: A 35cm-long, bright red, skinless sausage unique to Freiburg. Best served broiled in a bun with plenty of mustard. The vibrant red color and impressive length make it instantly recognizable at the M√ºnstermarkt.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A specialty of Freiburg's famous M√ºnstermarkt (Cathedral Market), the Lange Rote has been a local favorite for generations. The market dates back centuries and operates in the shadow of the magnificent Freiburg M√ºnster cathedral.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: M√ºnsterplatz Farmer's Market (M√ºnstermarkt) - look for the line of Wurststands all offering traditional Lange Rote. The market operates on the square in front of Freiburg M√ºnster cathedral.

hero_dishes.name: Black Forest Ham (Schwarzw√§lder Schinken)
hero_dishes.description: The real authentic Black Forest ham undergoes a three-month maturation process. Cured in salt for two weeks, then cold-smoked for several weeks, becoming almost black on the outside. It's Europe's best-selling smoked ham.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Thanks to Freiburg's proximity to the Black Forest, this traditional smoked ham has been produced for centuries using time-honored techniques. The long smoking process over fir wood gives it the distinctive dark exterior and rich flavor.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants like Zum Roten B√§ren (Germany's oldest inn, established 1120) and Oberkirchs Weinstube. Also available at the M√ºnstermarkt from local producers.

hero_dishes.name: Maultaschen
hero_dishes.description: A Swabian specialty from the Baden-W√ºrttemberg region - think German ravioli meets Polish pierogies. Flour dough wrapped around spinach, vegetables, cheese, and/or meat. Can be eaten in soup or as a main course.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This beloved dish originated in the Swabian region which includes Freiburg. The name roughly translates to 'mouth pockets' and legend says monks invented them to hide meat during Lent!
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Oma's K√ºche (Grandma's Kitchen) is a local favorite for well-prepared Maultaschen. Also served at traditional restaurants like Tacheles and Gro√üer Meyerhof.

hero_dishes.name: Flammkuchen
hero_dishes.description: A thin-crusted pizza-like dish topped with cream (cr√®me fra√Æche), onions, and bacon. Crispy, savory, and absolutely delicious - a local specialty of the Alsace-Baden region.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish comes from the border region between Germany and France (Alsace). Freiburg's proximity to France means it's a staple here. Traditionally baked in wood-fired ovens.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Waldrestaurant St. Valentin (7km from Freiburg) offers Alsace-style Flammekueche with beautiful mountain views and a beer garden.

hero_dishes.name: Schwarzw√§lder Kirschtorte (Black Forest Cake)
hero_dishes.description: The world-famous layered chocolate cake with whipped cream and cherries. To be authentic, it MUST be made with Kirschwasser (a clear cherry spirit from the Black Forest).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after the Black Forest region's specialty spirit, Kirschwasser. This cake became internationally famous but the authentic version must use real Kirschwasser, not cherry flavoring.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Available at traditional caf√©s and restaurants throughout Freiburg. Best enjoyed at establishments emphasizing Black Forest traditions.

signature_drinks.name: Kirschwasser
signature_drinks.description: A clear, strong fruit brandy made from sour cherries - the Black Forest's signature spirit. It's what makes Black Forest cake authentic and is beloved throughout the region.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as a digestif after hearty Black Forest meals. Also used in cooking and baking, especially in the famous Schwarzw√§lder Kirschtorte. Locals sip it neat in small glasses.

signature_drinks.name: Baden Wine
signature_drinks.description: Freiburg sits in the Baden wine region, Germany's warmest and sunniest wine-growing area. The region produces excellent white wines (especially M√ºller-Thurgau and Grauburgunder) and light reds.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at Weinstubes (wine taverns) like Oberkirchs Weinstube. Locals pair regional wines with traditional Black Forest cuisine. Wine culture is strong here thanks to the sunny climate and proximity to vineyards.
